turns.text: Let's go!

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: Okay.  Keep low.  Follow me.

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: C'mon Tim, move down, damn it!

turns.speaker: LEX
turns.text: Timmy!  The power is coming down, quick!

turns.speaker: LEX
turns.text: Do as he says!  The power's coming back, Timmy!

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: Timmy, let go!  You're gonna have to let go!  Count to three.  I'll catch you.

turns.speaker: LEX
turns.text: Timmy!  Do as he says!  Timmy!  Do as Dr. Grant says, quick!

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: Shhhh.  Tim, I'm right here below you.  Easy catch. One, two, three.  You count it yourself.  One, two, three - -

turns.speaker: LEX
turns.text: You're gonna get electrocuted  electrified!

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: It's am easy catch, you let - - go - - you do the counting, you count it, Tim.  One, two, three -- you do all the counting, okay?

turns.speaker: LEX
turns.text: Timmy, listen to Dr. Grant!

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: I'm coming up there Tim! I'm coming to get you!  Lex, I've got to get him!

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: I am gonna have to find the others and get you to a doctor.  Will you look after Tim, Lex?

turns.speaker: LEX
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: What works?

turns.speaker: LEX
turns.text: Phone security systems, everything works.  You ask for it, we got it!

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: You'll have to get use to Dr. Malcolm!  He suffers from a deplorable excess of personality, especially for a mathematician!

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Chaotician, actually!  Chaotician!

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: John doesn't subscribe to Chaos, particularly what it has to say about his little science project!

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: Codswollop!  Ian, you've never come close to explaining these concerns of yours about this island!

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I certainly have!  Very clearly!  Because of the behavior of the system in phase space!

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: A load, if I may say so. of fashionable number crunching, thatÂ¹s all it is!

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: John, John.

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: Don't do that!

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Dr. Grant, Dr. Sattler -- you've heard of Chaos Theory?

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: Your silence intrigues me.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: John, the kind of control you're attempting is not possible.  If there's one thing the history of evolution has taught us, it's that life will not be contained. Life breaks free.  It expands to new territories.  It crashes through barriers.  Painfully, maybe even.. dangerously, but and...well, there it is.

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: Alright Donald, alright, but just let him talk.  I want to hear all viewpoints.  I truly do.  I truly am.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Don't you see the danger, John, inherent in what you're doing here?  Genetic power is the most awesome force ever seen on this planet.  But you wield it like a kid who's found his dad's gun.

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: You don't give us our due credit.  Our scientists have done things no one could ever do before.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Your scientists were so preoccupied with whether or not they could that they didn't stop to think if they should.  Science can create pesticides, but it can't tell us not to use them.  Science can make a nuclear reactor, but it can't tell us not to build it!

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: But this is nature!  Why not give an extinct species a second chance?!  I mean, Condors. Condors are on the verge of extinction - - if I'd created a flock of them on the island, you wouldn't be saying any of this!  have anything to say at all!

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Hold on - - this is no species that was obliterated by deforestation or the building of a dam.  Dinosaurs had their shot.  Nature selected them for extinction.

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: I don't understand this Luddite attitude, especially from a scientist.  How could we stand in the light of discovery and not act?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: There's nothing that great about discovery.  What's so great about discovery?  It's a violent, penetrative act that scars what it explores.  What you call discovery I call the rape of the natural world!

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: I think perhaps I'll just sit down.  I don't suppose you think all that much of me now, do you?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: You're all right, John You're okay.  It's just you don't have intelligence.  You have "thinktelligence."  You think narrowly and call it "being focused."  You don't see the consequences.  You're very good at solving problems, at getting answers - - but you just don't know the right questions.

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: That will teach you to trust Grandpa.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Wait a minute?  What do you mean "worked"?  Everything is still off!
